What Is Radon?

Radon is radioactive gas. You cannot see it, smell it or taste it.

Radon comes from the breakdown natural elements found in our soil. As radium decays it produces radon gas. Each time this takes place, radioactive particles are emitted.

Why Does Radon Enter Our Homes?

When radon is present in the soil that surrounds our homes, it can be drawn into the basement by negative pressure found in the lower levels of all structures. This drawing effect pulls radon into the home and is then generally distributed throughout the house by the heating and cooling system.

How Does Radon Get In?

Radon is a gas, and as such it can easily pass through cracks, openings and most of the porous materials used to construct the foundations and floors of a home.
All major national and international organizations that have examined the health risks of radon agree that it is a lung carcinogen. The scientific community continues to conduct research to refine our understanding of the precise number of deaths attributable to radon. EPA and the National Cancer Institute (NCI) have independently placed that number at about 15,000 lung cancer deaths each year in the United States.

Other documented U.S. research yeilds that radon gas is second only to cigarette smoking as the leading cause of lung cancer death today. Both are preventable. The most susceptible victims are children, (because their lungs are still developing) smokers, (because of the doubling impact) and those that stay inside the home most of the day.
To learn more about radon gas and prevention, please use the following link below:
http://www.epa.gov/iaq/radon/radonqa1.html
